titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Jimmy Creech Papers, 1972-2014 RL.11114
titlestmt.author: Katrina Martin

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2020-09-02 10:26:02 -0400.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: James (Jimmy) Edward Creech (1944-) is a former United Methodist minister and activist. Creech was an ordained elder in The United Methodist Church from 1970 to 1999, serving as a minister in North Carolina and Omaha, Nebraska, and as the North Carolina Council of Churches' liaison with the North Carolina General Assembly. An outspoken advocate for gay rights, Creech performed dozens of holy union ceremonies as a pastor in the 1990s. The United Methodist Church passed legislation prohibiting such unions in 1996. In 1999, The United Methodist Church revoked his credentials of ordination following two church trials for defying this prohibition by conducting covenant ceremonies for two same-sex couples in 1997 and 1999. Since his defrocking, Creech has continued his work as an LGBTQ rights-activist, traveling across the country to push for civil and human rights for members of the LBGTQ community. The collection includes printed material, documentation of the church trials, and Creech's writings, including the original unedited manuscript of his memoir, Adam's Gift, initially entitled, The Church on Trial.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research.

accessrestrict.p: Access note. Collection contains electronic records that must be requested and accessed in our reading room. Contact Research Services with questions.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Jimmy Creech Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2015.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged into series: Church Life, Activist Work, and Writings. Arrangement and folder titles generated by creator.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: James (Jimmy) Edward Creech, born October 21, 1944, holds a master's of divinity from Duke University, granted in 1970. Following his ordination, he served as a minister at several churches in North Carolina, including Warsaw United Methodist Church and Fairmont United Methodist Church in Raleigh. He began to advocate for gay rights after a congregant came out to him in 1984. While at Fairmont between 1987 and 1990, he co-founded and was chairperson of the Raleigh Religious Network for Gay and Lesbian Equality, an ecumenical group designed to publicly challenge religious antigay rhetoric. Due to backlash following his outspoken advocacy for gay rights, including his decision to march in a gay pride parade, Creech was denied reappointment as minister of Fairmont in 1990. From 1991 to 1996, Creech was the Program Associate with the North Carolina Council of Churches. He was the council's legislative liaison with the North Carolina General assembly, and represented the council on issues including the abolition of the death penalty, farm workers, campaign finance reform, and the repeal of the Crimes Against Nature law. In 1996, he was appointed Senior Pastor at the First United Methodist Church in Omaha, Nebraska. In September, 1997, he joined two women in a "holy union" despite orders issued in 1996 by The United Methodist Church prohibiting such unions. After the union, he was suspended from ministry and was put on trial in March, 1998, by The United Methodist Church under the charge of violating the Order and Discipline of The United Methodist Church. The trial ended in Creech's acquittal, but he was not reappointed to First United Methodist Church, Omaha, as Senior Pastor. He took a voluntary leave of absence and returned to Raleigh. While in Raleigh, in 1999 Creech joined another same-sex couple in a holy union. He was again put on trial by the church, at which he was convicted and defrocked. Since the summer of 1998 and his defrocking in 1999, Creech has continued to advocate for LGBTQ rights, especially for gays and lesbians within faith communities. He has traveled around the country preaching in churches and speaking on college campuses about human and civil rights for members of the LGBT community. He has co-founded and guided several LGBTQ rights organizations, namely SoulForce and Faith in America. His memoir, Adam's Gift: A Memoir of a Pastor's Calling to Defy the Church's Persecution of Lesbians and Gays, published in 2011, details the church trials as well as his work as an ally for the gay community. Creech is retired and lives in Raleigh.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Jimmy Creech Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Katrina Martin, February 2016. Electronic records were processed by Matthew Farrell and Laurin Penland, July 2020.
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2015-0167; 2016-0265

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Rubenstein Library also holds the United Methodist Church Records, 1784-1984, bulk 1800-1940.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Organized into three series, Church Life, Activist Work, and Writings, the Jimmy Creech papers (12,375 items) contain correspondence, notes, research files, printed material, ephemera, clippings and articles, and audio recordings from Creech's time as a United Methodist minister and LGBT rights activist. The papers span 1981-2014, with a bulk of the collection covering the 1990s during which time he was a United Methodist minister in North Carolina, the Program Associate for the North Carolina Council of Churches, and eventually became the senior pastor at First United Methodist Church in Omaha, Nebraska. A bulk of the Church Life series covers the two church trials brought against Creech in 1998 and 1999 by The United Methodist Church for his conducting covenant ceremonies for same-sex couples. Much of this series consists of correspondence received by Creech from his supporters and opponents during these trials. The Activist Work series holds files from Creech's advocacy for civil and human rights, especially for members of the LGBT community. Activist Work series documents Creech's speaking engagements and attendance at conferences across the country in support of LGBT rights. This series also contains files from Creech's work against the death penalty, including correspondence with death row inmates in the 1990s. A part of the Activist Work series, The RRNGLE (Raleigh Religious Network for Gay and Lesbian Equality) subseries contains materials created and given to Creech by RRNGLE member Patricia Long. Creech was co-founder and chairperson of RRNGLE, an ecumenical group designed to publicly challenge religious antigay rhetoric. Long's files include interviews with RRNGLE members and documents pertaining to her efforts to publish a book on the organization. Original audiovisual material and electronic records are also included in the collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Church Life series documents Creech's work as a United Methodist minister in North Carolina and Omaha, Nebraska. The series contains papers beginning in 1981 from Creech's time at Warsaw United Methodist Church in Warsaw, NC through his defrocking in 1999. The bulk of the series comprises correspondence with parishioners and church officials, media coverage of his time as pastor including his sometimes controversial support of gay rights issues, church newsletters, and printed material. The First Trial and Second Trial subseries document the two church trials held in Nebraska that eventually led to Creech's defrocking in 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The First Trial subseries documents the trial held against Creech by The United Methodist Church in March, 1998. Creech was charged with violating the Order and Discipline of The United Methodist Church for celebrating a covenant ceremony for two women in Omaha, Nebraska in September, 1997. Subseries comprises correspondence, trial transcripts, clippings, and Creech's notes on the trial proceedings. Contains correspondence with Nebraska Bishop Joel Martinez and Creech's advisors, including his wife, Chris Weedy. Subseries contains defense team correspondence and notes. A bulk of the subseries contains positive letters of support Creech received during the trial as well as negative letters condemning his actions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Second Trial subseries contains Creech's documentation from his second trial held by The United Methodist Church on the charge of violating the Order and Discipline of The United Methodist Church for celebrating a holy union for two men in April 1999. The Second Trial subseries contains defense strategies, correspondence from the trial, clippings and other media coverage of the 1999 trial.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Activist Work series contains printed material, correspondence, documents concerning travel engagements, and media coverage of Creech's efforts as an activist during his time as an ordained minister and following the removal of his credentials of ordination. Series contains two subseries, Engagements and RRNGLE (Raleigh Religious Network for Gay and Lesbian Equality). Series comprises Creech's original files which tend to be both subject files as well his personal files about the organizations and projects he worked with. The series covers his advocacy for LGBT rights, primarily marriage equality and making faith communities welcoming to LGBT-identified congregants. Files contain his work to found and guide several organizations to support LGBT people of faith, namely Faith in America and Soulforce. Also included is correspondence with other religious LGBT activists, articles and clippings, and printed material. Series contains files related to his work against the death penalty. Creech had pastoral relationships with death row inmates in North Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Raleigh Religious Network for Gay and Lesbian Equality (RRNGLE) subseries contains files given to Creech by member Patricia Long. Files include organizational history and meeting minutes, printed material, and correspondence. Contains correspondence from Long's attempt to publish a book about the organization.
Audio tapes with interviews of RRNGLE members also provided by Patricia Long.

The bulk of the series consists of drafts of his memoir Adam's Gift, originally entitled The Church on Trial, and materials related to its publication in 2011.

did.unittitle: Homosexuality: An attempt at dialogue, Willie E. Frye
